My own group critique confirmed for me that although Mamdani remains the strong favorite, the extraordinary field configuration and polarizing context merit prudent discounting and a buffer vs. historic base rates. Therefore, I maintain the forecast at 77%.

Sociology (Urban Sociology).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After group deliberation, there is strong convergence across specialist domains—political science, campaign strategy, polling analysis, identity politics, and race/ethnicity studies—around the 75-77% range, with limited support for moving higher. The chief dissent (Sociology Identity Politics at 81% and Political Science Urban Political Machines at 82%) both arguably understate residual tail risks, especially the potential for a late anti-Mamdani realignment or a scandal affecting the candidate. Engagements in the deliberation phase reinforced how persistent uncertainties remain, given urban volatility, imperfect Democratic establishment unity, and the existence of plausible late-game realignment scenarios. Defenses of the consensus probability successfully highlight that risks exist (including shifts in identity coalitions, voter turnout shocks, and unpredictable narrative turns), meriting some discount from base-rate maximalism. I therefore see no reason to revise upwards or downwards and maintain the 77% probability.

Sociology (Identity Politics).reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation reaffirmed the high probability of Mamdani’s victory, with nearly all other forecasters converging on a probability in the high 70s or very low 80s, nearly all emphasizing the fractured field, NYC Democratic base rates, Mamdani’s polling lead, and the lack of evidence for a credible anti-Mamdani consolidation. Critiques of my slightly more optimistic 81% highlighted, credibly, that NYC politics—particularly when identity factors are highly salient and establishment unease persists—merit a slightly larger discount for tail risks: particularly the possibility of a sudden, face-saving withdrawal or deal between Adams and Cuomo, escalation of identity-based controversies, or late elite coordination/endorsement shift. Additionally, statistical prudence recommends not straying well above consensus base-rate estimates (which are 75-78% for Democratic nominees in the rare, fragmented field scenario), given the novel mix of persistent non-GOP challengers, incomplete party unity, and live national/ethnic controversy. While none of these risks appears likely at present, a slight downward adjustment better reflects the aggregate historical precedent and the converging views of specialists in turnout, campaign strategy, and NYC political history.

American Studies (Race and Ethnicity in.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, my confidence in my initial 77% probability is reinforced. Multiple disciplinary perspectives—campaign strategy, polling analysis, urban sociology, and NYC electoral history—consistently converge around a forecast in the high 70s, all citing the fractured opposition, magnitude and durability of Mamdani’s polling lead, and NYC’s overwhelming Democratic partisanship. Critiques of more optimistic forecasts (over 80%) appropriately note the non-negligible risk of late field consolidation, elite defection, or issue-driven backlash (e.g., over Israel/Palestine or policing), which historically can move several points even in structurally lopsided races. Conversely, arguments for a lower probability lack support given the present field structure, polling, and absence of signs for a dramatic consolidation. No new information undermined my initial weighting of risks or the ruling structural crosswinds. Therefore, I maintain my forecast at 77%.

question_details.title: Will Zohran Mamdani be elected Mayor of New York City in 2025?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-06-20 21:30:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/38665). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

New York City holds its mayoral race on November 4, 2025. The race is expected to be between:

* Zohran Mamdani, if he wins the Democratic nomination or possibly as the candidate of the [Working Families Party](https://www.cityandstateny.com/politics/2025/04/wfp-will-not-give-general-election-ballot-line-andrew-cuomo/404264/) if he doesn't.
* Andrew Cuomo, if he wins the Democratic nomination or as an [independent](https://nypost.com/2025/05/06/us-news/andrew-cuomo-will-run-on-independent-fight-and-deliver-ballot-line-if-he-doesnt-win-nyc-dem-primary/) if he doesn't. 
* Eric Adams, current mayor of NY, elected as a Democrat for his first term but now [running as an independent](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/03/nyregion/eric-adams-independent-mayor.html). 
* Curtis Sliwa, founder of the [Guardian Angels](https://www.guardianangels.org/) and the Republican candidate.

NYC mayoral polling averages can be found at the [RaceToTheWH.com website](https://www.racetothewh.com/nycmayorpolling).

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":38665,"question_id":37886}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if Zohran Mamdani is elected mayor of New York City in the [2025 New York City mayoral election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_New_York_City_mayoral_election).
question_details.fine_print: This question may resolve as No before the general election if Mamdani loses the Democratic primary and announces he will not run in the general election.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**How Trump’s 'brand of despotism' set the stage for a 'looming clash'**
President Donald Trump is urging Mayor Eric Adams to drop out of New York City’s 2025 mayoral race, arguing that a smaller field would make it easier to defeat the Democratic nominee, Assemblyman Zohran Mamdani. A Marist poll released on September 16 shows Mamdani leading former Gov. Andrew Cuomo by 21 percentage points in a four‑way race that also includes Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa and Adams. John Whitlow, a law professor at City University of New York, writes in The Nation that New York City is the epicenter of a political and economic battle between Trump’s “brand of despotism,” rooted in 1980s real‑estate politics, and Mamdani’s “democratic socialism.” Whitlow calls Trump’s labeling of Mamdani a “communist” inaccurate, noting that Mamdani identifies as a “democratic socialist” in the vein of Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio‑Cortez. Whitlow argues that Trump’s real‑estate background—acquiring Manhattan land after the 1970s fiscal crisis—provides a “through line” to his governance style, and that Mamdani’s housing platform threatens the neoliberal compact that has dominated the city’s economy since the 1970s.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 18, 2025 08:00 PM
Source:[Alternet](https://www.alternet.org/the-right-wing/trump-mamdani-nyc/)

**NY Democratic Party chair not endorsing Mamdani**
New York Democratic Party Chair Jay Jacobs announced on Thursday that he will not endorse Zohran Mamdani in the New York City mayoral race. Jacobs said, 'Mr. Mamdani and I are in agreement that America's greatest problem is the continued growth of income disparity in our nation,' but added, 'On how to address it -- we fundamentally disagree.' He also criticized the ‘fear mongering’ around Mamdani’s campaign and his views on Israel, stating that the Democratic Socialists of America does not represent the Democratic Party’s principles. Mamdani, who won the Democratic primary in a surprise victory over former Governor Andrew Cuomo, has been a vocal critic of Israel’s actions in Gaza and has threatened to order the NYPD to arrest Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu if he visits the city. Jacobs’ decision follows Governor Kathy Hochul’s endorsement of Mamdani, who praised his ‘can‑do spirit’ while noting disagreements on policy. Neither Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer nor House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries has endorsed Mamdani, despite meeting with him. New York State Senator Mike Gianaris called Jacobs’ refusal to endorse ‘disgraceful’ in a post on X, questioning the party leader’s role. A recent Emerson College Poll found 43% of respondents support Mamdani, compared with 28% for Cuomo, 10% for Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa, and 7% for incumbent Mayor Eric Adams. The general election is scheduled for November 4, 2025.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 18, 2025 07:32 PM
Source:[The Hill](https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/5510930-jay-jacobs-not-endorsing-mamdani/)

**Mayor Eric Adams, Andrew Cuomo buried below Zohran Mamdani, Curtis...**
The New York City ballot for the November 4 election, released Wednesday, places Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani and Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa at the top of the mayoral line, followed by Conservative Party candidate Irene Estrada and Mamdani again as the Working Families Party pick. Sliwa also appears on his independent line Protect Animals. Incumbent Mayor Eric Adams is positioned at the bottom of the first line, next to the write‑in box, under his independent line ‘Safe & Affordable.’ Former Governor Andrew Cuomo appears on a second row under the independent line ‘Fight and Deliver,’ sandwiched between Jim Walden and Jose Hernandez. The order was set by state law; the established parties always come first, and independent lines are ordered by filing date, according to Board of Elections spokesperson Vincent Ignizio. Adams’ campaign has struggled since his primary loss, with polls showing support falling to only a few percentage points. Absentee ballots will be mailed Friday.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 17, 2025 10:10 PM
Source:[New York Post](https://nypost.com/2025/09/17/us-news/mayor-eric-adams-andrew-cuomo-buried-below-zohran-mamdani-curtis-sliwa-on-cluttered-nyc-mayoral-election-ballot/)

**Mayor Eric Adams, Andrew Cuomo buried below Zohran Mamdani, Curtis Sliwa on cluttered NYC mayoral election ballot**
New York City’s sample Nov. 4 ballot, released Wednesday, lists Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani and Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa as the first two options, followed by Conservative Party candidate Irene Estrada, then Mamdani again on the Working Families Party line, and Sliwa again on his Protect Animals line. Incumbent Mayor Eric Adams and former Governor Andrew Cuomo are buried deeper down the ballot. A city Board of Elections spokesperson said the order of the nine candidates was set by state law, with 'The established parties are always first,' according to Vincent Ignizio. He added that independent bids were ordered by filing date, and 'Curtis filed first, so he’s the first independent body listed.' The Board of Elections certified the ballot last week, and absentee ballots will start being mailed out on Friday. Polls show Adams’ support is slowly dwindling to just a few percentage points.

Publish date: September 17, 2025 10:10 PM
Source:[nypost.com](https://nypost.com/2025/09/17/us-news/mayor-eric-adams-andrew-cuomo-buried-below-zohran-mamdani-curtis-sliwa-on-cluttered-nyc-mayoral-election-ballot/)

**NY Poll Monitor: What to Expect from the Zohran Mamdani vs. Andrew Cuomo Showdown**
According to the article, the race for New York City mayor is shaping up as one of the most intense political battles in recent years. Andrew Cuomo is attempting a comeback as an independent candidate, while Zohran Mamdani is consolidating his position as the Democratic favorite for the November election. Polls and surveys are beginning to show trends less than two months before the election.

**NYC mayor: I'm looking forward to meeting with Netanyahu during UN General Assembly**
New York City Mayor Eric Adams announced that he will meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during the United Nations General Assembly in New York, stating that the city will "welcome" the Israeli leader like other dignitaries and that the NYPD is not preparing arrest warrants for foreign heads of state.  Adams emphasized that the city respects the rule of law and diplomatic immunity, saying, 'You have a right to come here and voice the positions from your country. And we respect the rule of law here. We don't react in a reckless manner [by] stating that we were going to arrest a dignitary that's here. There are processes that are in place, and we will respect and we will carry them out accordingly.'  In contrast, mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani, the heavy favorite in the November election, has publicly declared that he would arrest Netanyahu if he visits New York, citing an International Criminal Court warrant, although U.S. law bars local governments from enforcing such warrants.  The article notes that Adams is a firm supporter of Israel and is polling in third place, behind Mamdani and former governor Andrew Cuomo, who also supports Israel but has criticized the Gaza war.  The piece was published by The Times of Israel on September 19 2025.

**Activists Deliver Petitions Urging Schumer and Jeffries to Endorse Mamdani**
Activists have gathered more than 85,000 signatures to urge Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Majority Leader Mike Jeffries to endorse Zohran Mamdani, the 33‑year‑old Democratic nominee for New York City mayor. Gov. Kathy Hochul endorsed Mamdani earlier this week, but Schumer and Jeffries have yet to publicly endorse him. Liz Hohenberger of Our Revolution said the petition drive aims to "over the line" to secure endorsement: 'We're delivering over 85,000 petition signatures asking for Senator Schumer and Representative Jeffries to honor the primary elections and endorse the democratically elected nominee Zohran Mamdani for New York City mayor.' Jeffries declined to comment, saying he would speak later. Schumer met with Mamdani last week and said, 'we had a very good conversation. We know each other well, and those conversations are continuing.' Polls show Mamdani with a double‑digit lead over former Gov. Andrew Cuomo, with the Republican candidate in third place and incumbent Mayor Eric Adams in fourth. The petition has drawn support from figures such as Alexandria Ocasio‑Cortez and Bernie Sanders, while others like Rep. Tom Suozzi oppose Mamdani: 'Sometimes change is more important than unity. And I think that the Democrats, we have to work on our brand. And I think that the message that Mr. Mamdani is standing for is not something that I agree with.' Trump criticized Hochul’s endorsement on Truth Social, calling Mamdani a "Liddle Communist": 'Governor Kathy Hochul of New York has endorsed the 'Liddle' Communist, Zohran Mamdani, running for Mayor of New York.' The article presents both activist and political perspectives, quoting statements from key figures and reporting polling data without overt editorializing.

**More New York Democrats coalesce behind Zohran Mamdani, but key holdouts remain**
A new poll released by NBC New York shows Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani leading the mayoral race with a double‑digit margin over former Gov. Andrew Cuomo, even if other candidates drop out. The poll also indicates that Mamdani has a commanding lead if all candidates remain in the race. Smikle, a longtime Democratic strategist, noted that ‘the calculus for Hochul and Heastie…is to find a way to embrace the movement he’s created.’ Hochul said, ‘New York State and New York City are at our best when we stand together against those who attempt to tear us apart.’ Heastie described Mamdani as an optimist promising a better direction for the city. Mamdani echoed the call for unity, saying, ‘This is a time for unity. It is a time for strength, and it is a time to speak in one voice.’ The article also mentions that the MTA lost nearly $1 billion in 2024 due to toll and fare evasion, and that Mamdani plans to make public transit free. **Trump says Zohran Mamdani likely to be New York's next mayor unless...**
President Donald Trump said on a White House dinner that he believes Democrat Zohran Mamdani is likely to become New York City’s next mayor unless two of the three major candidates in the race drop out. Trump answered a reporter’s question with a firm ‘No’ when asked if he had urged any candidate to quit, but added that he would like to see two people leave the race so it becomes a one‑on‑one contest. Trump said, ‘I would like to see two people drop out and have it be one‑on‑one, and I think that’s a race that could be won.’

Mamdani, a 33‑year‑old democratic socialist, has been the presumptive favorite after defeating former Gov. Andrew Cuomo in the Democratic primary. Cuomo remains on the ballot as an independent, as does incumbent Mayor Eric Adams, while Republican Curtis Sliwa, founder of the Guardian Angels, also competes.

Trump’s intermediaries reportedly reached out to people close to Adams to discuss whether he might abandon his reelection bid for a federal job, according to sources speaking to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity. Adams, who was indicted on corruption charges last year, has repeatedly denied quitting, telling reporters, ‘No pressure, no diamonds…just because people yell at you and call your names, you’re supposed to succumb to that? That’s not what I do.’

Cuomo called on Adams to drop out, saying, ‘If Mamdani is the existential threat, if you believe that, then at a point you should defer to the strongest candidates.’ Sliwa countered, ‘The assumption here is that Eric Adams voters, if he does drop out, are all going to jump to Cuomo. That ain’t happening.’ He added, ‘I can assure you for the 9,852nd time in this campaign I’ve had to answer this: I’m not dropping out. I’m in it until November 4.’

The article, published by the Daily Mail Online on September 5 2025, reports on a dinner hosted by Trump with tech executives and includes quotes from Trump, Adams, Cuomo, and Sliwa, as well as background on the candidates’ standings and recent political developments.

summary:
All forecasting experts agree that Zohran Mamdani is the strong favorite to be elected Mayor of New York City in the 2025 election. The main reasons cited across perspectives include his status as the Democratic nominee in a city with an overwhelming Democratic registration and base rate, his robust and consistent double-digit lead in all major polls, the high levels of enthusiasm and effective mobilization among progressives, younger, and minority voters, and the significant fragmentation of the opposition vote between Andrew Cuomo, Eric Adams, and Curtis Sliwa, making it very difficult for any one rival to consolidate enough support to challenge him. Most experts estimate Mamdani's probability of victory at 77%, with the exception of two slightly higher forecasts (81% and 82%) from identity politics and urban machine experts, respectively.

Key risk factors identified are: possible late withdrawal or consolidation among the opposition candidates (Cuomo and Adams) that could unify anti-Mamdani voters; lack of full establishment Democratic support (notably Schumer and Jeffries withholding endorsements); the potential for late-breaking scandals, negative campaigning, or external crises (particularly focused on Mamdani’s foreign policy stances); and the historical volatility of polling with progressive/outsider candidates. However, these scenarios are considered low-probability given current polling, organizational, and field dynamics.

The consensus yes-scenario is that Mamdani retains his current polling lead, the opposition remains divided, and Democratic turnout patterns hold, resulting in his election by a comfortable margin. The consensus no-scenario would require a dramatic, unified anti-Mamdani push, a major scandal, or unprecedented turnout collapse among his supporters—considered unlikely by all experts at this stage. In summary, the expert community sees Mamdani’s election as highly probable given NYC’s partisan baseline, fractured opposition, and polling, with only modest risk from extraordinary late developments.
